title: Sterilization and union instability in Brazil

references.raw: Hopkins, K. & Potter, J. (1997) Are Brazilian women really begging for caesarean? XI Encontro Nacional de Estudos Populacionais.

references.title: Brazil’s fertility decline, 1965–95: a fresh look at key factors.
references.raw: Martine, G. (1996) Brazil’s fertility decline, 1965–95: a fresh look at key factors. Population and Development Review 22(1), 47–73.

references.title: Fertility and family planning in Brazil.

references.title: Fertility and union dynamics in Brazil.

references.title: Inequities and policy dilemmas in the course of an unregulated, spontaneous fertility transition: the case of Brazil.

(2001) Inequities and policy dilemmas in the course of an unregulated, spontaneous fertility transition: the case of Brazil. IUSSP XXIV General Poulation Conference, Salvador Bahia, Brazil.

references.raw: United Nations (1996) Levels and Trends of Contraceptive Use as Assessed in 1994. ST/ESA/ SER.A/146, New York, 1996, cited in Potter (1999). Sterilization and union instability in Brazil 469

references.title: Male attitude to unplanned pregnancies in Jamaica.

references.title: The Effect of Marital Dissolution on Contraceptive Protection.
references.raw: Bumpass, L. & Rindfuss, R. R. (1982) The Effect of Marital Dissolution on Contraceptive Protection. Center for Demography and Ecology, University of Wisconsin-Madison.

references.title: The fertility transition in Brazil: causes and consequences. In
references.raw: Carvalho, J. A. M. D. & Wong, L. R. (1996) The fertility transition in Brazil: causes and consequences. In Guzman, J. M., Sigh, S., Rodriguez, G. & Pantediles, E. A. (eds) The Fertility Transition in Latin America. IUSSP International Studies in Demography, Oxford University Press.

references.raw: 468 T. Leone and A. HindeGreene, M. (1991) The importance of being married: marriage choice and its consequences in Brazil. Doctoral Thesis, University of Pennsylvania.
